Executive Summary:



Airgas USA, LLC. an Air Liquide Company (Airgas USA, LLC. commonly known as AMG - Airgas Merchant Gases) operates a liquid hydrogen (LH2) transfill facility with thirty one (31) employees in Etiwanda, California.  The facility is manned 24 hours per day. The Etiwanda hydrogen process receives LH2 by tractor trailer that is stored onsite in a single bulk storage vessel (5,860 lbs at approximately -420 ?F) before being vaporized and transferred into gas tube trailers then distributed to customers.  Distribution trucks containing approximately 590 lbs of gaseous hydrogen are filled on a daily basis. Each is monitored and analyzed, increasing operational safety.

 

On or about June 25th, 2018 this transfill facility and process will be expanded and the single bulk storage vessel will hold a capacity of 7,810 lbs LH2; the planned inventory for the covered process will be 40,000 pounds (lbs) of hydrogen.  The covered process will exceed the listed regulatory threshold quantity (TQ) of 10,000 lbs for hydrogen and will be subject to U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions, written in Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations, Part 68 (40 CFR Part 68) (the RMP Rule), as well as the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) program written in California's Code of Regulations Title 19.  CalARP includes some additional state requirements and is implemented at the local government level by the Certified Unified Program Agencies (CUPA's) which determine the level of detail in the RMPs, review RMPs, conduct facility inspections and provide public access to RMP information.  The San Bernardino County Fire Department (CUPA) is the implementing agency for the Airgas Etiwanda covered process.  Airgas' commitment to safety and environmental protection extends beyond its gates.  As part of the community, we have a responsibility to our customers and to those who live in the surrounding area.

Hydrogen stored and transfilled on site is listed as a highly hazardous substance under the EPA Risk Management Plan (RMP), OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations and the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) program.  The Airgas Etiwanda, CA onsite inventory of hydrogen will be in excess of 10,000 pounds making the hydrogen transfill process and its connected equipment a PSM/RMP/CalARP covered process.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:



The highly flammable and hazardous nature of hydrogen in the process makes it necessary for Airgas to observe certain safety precautions to prevent unnecessary human and environmental exposure and to reduce the potential threat to personnel and nearby members of the community.  Airgas' policy is to comply with all applicable federal and state rules and regulations.  This Executive Summary sets forth some of the management systems in place to implement the accidental release and prevention program.  Airgas has also implemented specific chemical prevention steps to help prevent potential scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors.  The following examples of the types of safety features in place:  (1) Release Mitigation - Emergency stop buttons to isolate hydrogen sources; personal protective equipment (personal gas detectors, protective outerwear clothing, intrinsically safe devices, safety goggles, shoes, etc.)  (2) System Integrity - Automatic control and manual valves that provides isolation for hydrogen process equipment, check valves on hydrogen loading lines and pressure safety valves for the process piping and vessels.  (3) Facility and Environment - Contracted emergency response specialist, Safety-Kleen, to support the Etiwanda plant emergency response plan.



Employee Participation (EP)

Airgas has developed a written plan of action and Etiwanda employee/operators are expected to participate in the accidental r

elease prevention program (RMP/PSM).   Employees are trained on and provided access to the hydrogen transfill process safety information.  Specific actions an employee can be involved in the accident prevention program are documented in the Employee Participation plan.  Forms of participation include being part of a PHA, a PSSR, and/or being involved in incident investigation. Employees participate in monthly safety meetings where process safety issues are discussed and corrective actions are developed, and they are involved in the review of the covered process operating procedures annually to ensure they are current, accurate and recommend any necessary changes.

 

 

Process Safety Information (PSI)

Airgas keeps a variety of technical documents onsite and in the company's electronic document control system that are used to help maintain safe operation of its processes.  These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, equipment design/configuration information, specific chemical inventories and operation limits for key process parameters - all key information for operating the process safely.  Process operators are trained to operate the process using process controls and instrumentation within these safe operating limits.

 

The Facility Manager is responsible for maintaining up-to-date process safety information.  A table summarizing the reference documents and their location is readily accessible as part of the written employee participation. 

 

 

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

Airgas has a risk management program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled.  The covered process underwent an initial process hazard analysis (PHA) and will continue to undergo periodic review/re-validations at least every five years or as required by Management Of Change (MOC).   The PHA team consists of members with the appropriate experience to define the hazards and mitigating controls of the process a

nd also represents a cross-section of the employees working in the process.  For future PHA reviews, local and corporate management will review the PHA team findings and develop a resolution action plan for each item, which will be documented, tracked and ultimately closed in the Airgas action item database tracking system.  Facility Manager is responsible for prioritizing and tracking implementation of the action plan to closure.

 

 

Operating Procedures (OP)

Airgas maintains controlled written procedures that address various modes of liquefied and gaseous hydrogen process operations, such as: (1) initial startup; (2) normal operations; (3) emergency shutdown; (4) normal shutdown and; (5) startup after turnaround or emergency shutdown.   The hydrogen transfer operation will not operate under temporary or emergency operations.  If these conditions occur, plant operators and management will evaluate the circumstances and either shut the plant down or complete an MOC, including and emergency MOC.  Additionally, the emergency shutdown procedure includes conditions that will prompt a shutdown and identifies qualified and responsible operators to complete the steps in a safe and timely manner.

 

Airgas operating procedures have safe operating limits identified along with consequences of unsafe deviation.  Procedures further provide steps for operators to take that will correct or avoid an unsafe deviation.  Airgas procedures are used by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators.  These procedures are reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate.

 

 

Training (TRN)

Airgas has implemented a training program for all employee/operators involved in the hydrogen covered process.  All employees receive a combination of classroom, computer-based (CBT) and hands-on training that addresses such topics as:  general orientation, facility rules and practices, process safety information, normal and emergency operating proce

dures, health and safety consideration, use of safety procedures and equipment, incident investigation and emergency response.  In addition, all operators are required to attend refresher training at least every three years.  Training is documented and tracked in a local facility matrix and electronically in the Airgas University training system.

 

 

Mechanical Integrity (MI)

Airgas has established mechanical integrity (MI) practices and procedures, based on preventative philosophy, to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief valves and vent systems, controls and interlocks, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition.  The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests; (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures.  In combination, these written activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment.  The MI program assists with the verification and suitability of new and existing process equipment and, as well as quality control of spare parts and modifications to existing process equipment.

 

 

Management of Change (MOC)

Airgas' management of change (MOC) procedure has established the requirements for ensuring proposed process or equipment changes or changes indirectly affecting processes are evaluated, approved and documented prior to implementation through the use of a management of change process.  The MOC procedure outlines the requirements for documenting, evaluating the impact, and approving planned deviations from procedure.  All MOC's are submitted, reviewed by subject matter specialist (such as Engineering, Risk Management, Operations, Health and Safety), approved, tracked and closed using an electronic approval and tracking system.  Upon closure, personnel whose assigned job functions are impacted by the MOC, are briefed and /or trained

in the MOC requirements.

 

 

Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSR)

Airgas ensures the safety of new/modified facilities or processes before placing those facilities or processes into service through the use of pre-startup safety reviews (PSSR's).  PSSR's are intended to ensure safety through confirmation that:  (1) construction and equipment are in accordance with design specifications; (2) safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place and adequate; (3) PHA's have been performed and recommendations resolved before startup of new plants or processes; (4) MOC requirements have been satisfied for modified facilities; and (5) training has been completed and documented for affected operator/employees.

 

 

Compliance Audits (CA)

To help ensure the accident prevention program is functioning properly, Airgas conducts an audit to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accidental release prevention program are being implemented.  Compliance audits are conducted at least every three years.  Resolutions to recommendations are documented, tracked and closed.  Once the resolutions have been completed, changes are communicated to operating, maintenance and other employees whose work assignments are in the covered process and who may be affected by the recommendations or actions.  Training and communication is documented.

 

Incident Investigation (II)

Airgas defines management systems and establishes the requirements for communicating, investigating and reporting of incidents at all facilities through the use of an Incident Investigation and reporting procedure.  Airgas documents incident and subsequent investigation, follow up actions, and closure in an electronic document control system.  The Facility Manager is responsible for maintaining a log and tracking incidents and corrective actions through completion.  Results of findings and corrective actions are shared with employee/operators who could be affected by the findings.

Reports are retained for at least five years to be reviewed during future PHA's and revalidations.

 

 

Safe & Hot Work Permit System (HWP)

Airgas has a safe & hot work permit system in place to help ensure worker and process safety.  This system is comprised of a group of corporate procedures, standards and forms under the life safety program.  Procedures in place include:  (1) energy control; (2) safe work; (3) hot work; (4) confined space entry.  Plant personnel are trained on these safe work practices to ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed professionally and safely.



Contractors (CON)

Airgas uses contractors to supplement its own workforce when maintenance activities exceed the capabilities or time available for their own employee/operators.  Contractors are made aware of the potential dangers involved with a system covered by PSM/RMP.  Procedures are in place to make sure that contractors:  (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, and (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, prior to their beginning work. Periodically contractors are evaluated to ensure that both their safety performance and training required for work on the hydrogen system meets Airgas's safety standards.

 



Five-Year Accident History (AH)

The Etiwanda hydrogen transfill facility has had no accident resulting in either on or offsite effects in the last five (5) years for the covered hydrogen process.

 

 

Emergency Response Program Information (ERP/EAP)

The Etiwanda hydrogen transfill plant is a non-responding facility and has developed a written emergency action plan.  The plan outlines action to be taken at the plant for handling small releases, and if larger the communication to emergency responders, local response agencies, and outside agency notification procedures in the event of a hydrogen release.  The emergency plan provides

for the evacuation of Etiwanda facility personnel and visitors.  The Etiwanda facility has provided their emergency response plan to and coordinates the plan annually with the local Rancho Cucamonga Fire Department, part of the San Bernardino County Fire Department (CUPA).  Should an emergency involving the release of hydrogen occur that will have off-site consequences Airgas will contact the Etiwanda Fire Department and local support authorities, who will coordinate action for the affected community.

 

 

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Safety is an inherent part of the culture at Airgas and enhancements in safety and operations are actively discussed and supported.  The Etiwanda hydrogen transfill facility continues to review its processes for possibilities of improvement to the covered hydrogen process, operational methods, and new technology to lower risk. In conclusion of our most recent Process Hazard Analysis (PHA), the Etiwanda facility plans to:

(1) Glad Hand locks to isolate trailer from connection to a tractor during filling to prevent hose rupture.

(2) Signage to indicate use of nitrogen for inerting purposes.

(3) Camera installation to monitor site for safety and security purposes.
